title: The celebrity photographer's bohemian retreat on the Isle of Wight
text:
25 shares 2
View
comments
She was the David Bailey of her day.
Julia Margaret Cameron, celebrity photographer of Victorian times and famous Isle of Wight resident, would have felt at home with the hubbub earlier this year over the wedding of Sherlock star Benedict Cumberbatch to Sophie Hunter on the island, and their plea for privacy.
Cameron, a great-aunt of Virginia Woolf, lived at Freshwater Bay, the bohemian retreat of poets, writers and artists, and she often helped her neighbour Alfred, Lord Tennyson avoid his adoring public.
Inspiring: Sea stack at Freshwater Bay, Isle of Wight. Looking west towards Tennyson Down
Cameron lived here because of Tennyson. After meeting the poet in 1860, she became a frequent guest at his home, Farringford, until he pointed out bluntly there were two cottages nearby for sale
She bought both, one for family and one for guests, later uniting them with a central crenellated tower.
Dimbola Lodge was Cameron’s home for 15 years. It was rescued from demolition in the 1990s and is now a museum. It was where she learned her craft.
 Next Lederhosen, low-cut blouses and LOTS of beer! Six million... Diving into shark-infested waters: What swimming with the... La Dolce Vita: Oozing timeless glamour, STUNNING photographs... An Inspector Calls: Golf, grouse and gourmet dinner at a... 25 shares For her 48th birthday, Cameron was given a camera by her daughter. She turned a chicken coop into a studio and coal cellar into a darkroom and set to work, photographing Charles Darwin, the poets Robert Browning and Henry Longfellow – and Tennyson, of course.
The studio has long gone, but a room full of dressing-up clothes for her early portraits is near her bedroom – she even had a bay window installed there so that she could keep an eye out for passers-by. No photogenic tourist was safe.
In this the bicentenary year of Cameron’s birth, a changing selection of original prints joins those portraits of Victorian celebrities in this quirky museum.
Cameron’s birth will also be marked with exhibitions of her work at both the Science Museum and the Victoria & Albert Museum in London.
Alum Bay Cliffs, Headon Warren, Isle of Wight
One Dimbola gallery is devoted to the Isle of Wight Festival, held in 1970 close to the property, and where Jimi Hendrix gave his last live UK performance – hence the statue of the guitarist in the garden.
The Freshwater poets and writers used to make regular trips around the island, and it is still picturesque today – from chalk downs to the dramatic ravine of Shanklin Chine.
I ended my own trip to the Isle of Wight with a visit to the striking Quarr Abbey.
In its delightful cafe in a walled garden bordered by espaliered pear trees, I had a frozen dessert from Minghella, the local gourmet ice-cream maker – just like Benedict and Sophie did at their wedding.
TRAVEL FACTS For more information, go to visitisleofwight.co.uk . For details on Dimbola Lodge, go to dimbola.co.uk and for Shanklin Chine go to shanklinchine.co.uk .
Travel to Ryde by hovercraft takes ten minutes from Southsea (hovertravel.co.uk) or 22 minutes by catamaran from Portsmouth (wightlink.co.uk).
Science Museum exhibition opens on September 24 and the V&A show from November 28.
